body:
Ha!  I just posted about a very similar issue in the google group with has_many :through — namely, the << operator adds records to via the join table without any checks for existence also.

*and the uniq option only applies to how associated objects are retrieved, not stored*

So if, in my use case, I have options set on the join table, I'm forced to do an extra exists? check to make sure I don't get duplicate join records.

I would it would make more sense to either:

1) Have uniq check on create as well
2) Have a different option (like uniq_on_create) that checks for an existing join record.  I'm of two minds as to whether an exception should be raised if a record already exists or not.. my gut says it would succeed without actually creating a record, but I'd imagine there's precedent in other ActiveRecord calls.
